abstract.p: Lawrence Van Gelder column reports on coming cultural events: 50th season of Marlboro Music School and Festival, 42nd season of Washington Square Music festival, exhibition of late Gothic and Renaissance stained glass from Germany and Switzerland at J Paul Getty Museum of Los Angeles and dance program at Wave Hill in the Bronx; photos (M)

block.p: Golden Year Celebrating its 50th season, the Marlboro Music School and Festival begins at 8:30 on Saturday night, when the pianist Richard Goode, starting his first year as artistic director with the pianist Mitsuko Uchida, performs in the Haydn Trio No. 35 on a program that includes works by Debussy and Brahms. At Marlboro College in Vermont musicians from around the world will participate in the seven-week retreat, offering unlimited rehearsal time for the exploration of chamber works and, on weekends through Aug. 13, public concerts. This year's composer in residence is Thomas Ades. Information: (802) 254-2394.

All for Bach The 42nd season of the free Washington Square Music festival will open at 8 tomorrow night, when Kenneth Cooper leads the Festival Baroque Band in an all-Bach program. The concert takes place near the statue of Garibaldi in the southeast quadrant of the park. In case of rain, it moves to New York University's Frederick Loewe Theater, 35 West Fourth Street, Greenwich Village. Information: (212) 431-1088.

Living Color In Germany and Switzerland in the late Gothic and Renaissance eras, the art of stained glass attained new heights. From a collaborative effort between draftsmen who drew the pictorial designs and artists who rendered enduring images of storytelling and devotion came stained-glass church windows and small panels in private homes. Beginning tomorrow, more than 60 glass panels and some 80 drawings, with a focus on works designed by Albrecht Durer and Hans Holbein the Younger, go on view at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles. ''Painting on Light: Drawings and Stained Glass in the Age of Durer and Holbein'' continues through Sept. 24. Information: (310) 440-7300.

Lawn Art Accompanied by a Korean percussion ensemble, a dance exploration of the vision of Chinese philosophers. Set to music by Pergolesi and Albinoni, a dance duet. And a new composition inspired by Indonesian gamelan music but performed on found objects and original instruments like a clay-pot marimba and a saw-blade gong. These are the attractions when Dancing in the Streets and Wave Hill, the estate in Riverdale, the Bronx, present ''Dances for Wave Hill.'' The outdoor performances by the Nai-Ni Chen Dance Company, Guta Hedewig, and Lisa Townsend and Terry Dame's Junkyard Gamelan are scheduled for 6:30 p.m. Wednesday, 5 p.m. Sunday and 6:30 p.m. on July 19. Information: (718) 549-3200.
